awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cultural Economic Understandings of Work under Ecological Restoration
awd_abstract_narration:
Responses to the scale of environmental degradation today requires the coordination of multiple workers with specialized labors, skills, and knowledge systems. Existing research exploring the relationship between environmental action and labor tend to focus on individual actors who participate voluntarily. Less is known about how workers contracted in projects of ecological restoration come to understand themselves and their labor. This doctoral dissertation research investigates the efficacy of ecological restoration through its impacts on worker behavior. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, findings from this research will be shared with governmental and non-governmental organizations, and others with the aim of improving working conditions for those actively involved in ameliorating environmental pollution and degradation. The project also endeavors to enhance public understanding of science and the scientific method, specifically regarding the scientific management of ecological health.

While restoration projects are critical for ensuring the integrity of the biosphere, the research hypothesizes that the responsibilities of carrying them out are unevenly distributed, often along lines of pre-existing social inequalities. It extends theoretical perspectives from the anthropology of work and environmental anthropology, while integrating under-represented perspectives into the history and sociology of science. The doctoral researcher uses a combination of ethnographic, visual, and archival methods (including infrastructural mapping, reflexive memos, participant observation, life history interviews, workflow observation, and textual and discourse analysis) to investigate the infrastructural labor of ecological restoration and demonstrate how environmental injustice plays out in various settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF DDRIG-funded project "Cultural Economic Understandings of Work under Ecological Restoration" took place over a period of 18 months, combining archival and ethnographic research to examine the restoration of the river Ganga in contemporary India. By juxtaposing the material practices of restoring the river with narratives of variously situated actors who implement or are impacted by them, my research examined the heterogenous, and often contradictory, desires and visions of recovery that are linked to ecological restoration. Thus, far from being a replicable technical endeavor as it is often understood in mainstream discourses of environmental management, my research positions restoration as always already implicated with sociocultural dynamics and power relations that have tremendous implications for how we care for, repair, and maintain the environment. 


I used a mixed-method approach to collect data for my project. For the first four months, I conducted archival research at the National Archives in New Delhi and the State Archives in Lucknow, examining government documents, policy reports, news articles, and historical records to understand the historical and political context of Ganga’s restoration. The rest of the research period was spent conducting fieldwork in Varanasi, India, a site of immense religious and cultural importance. I conducted participant observation in several riverfront and public spaces in the city, attended various religious ceremonies, scientific conferences, observed restoration activities, and participated in community events associated with the river. Where possible and ethical, I took photographs and collected found images such as in the form of pamphlets, advertisements, maps, and newspaper images. In addition, I conducted a mix of semi-structured and informal interviews with government officials, members of the local city council, civil engineers and scientists working at the local university, religious leaders, members of civil society organizations, social and environmental justice activists, boatsmen, fishermen, street vendors, sanitation workers, waste pickers, and residents impacted by restoration projects. By analyzing the various discourses and practices associated with river restoration, I explored the cultural, ethical, and political logics that informed people's care for the river, and how the performance of care, in turn, materially and subjectively impacted their lives. 


My research addresses crucial questions of precarity, disposability, and labor within the context of ecological restoration, examining how marginalized communities are subjected to precarious labor conditions and environmental risks. Its findings inform more effective and equitable environmental management strategies, ensuring that the benefits of restoration efforts are shared more broadly so that vulnerable communities are not disproportionately burdened by environmental degradation and amelioration. My research also advances scholarship on the understudied intersection of religion, scientific practice, and everyday ethics in environmentalism, focusing on how restoration intersects with ethical and moral practice, shaped by local and cultural understandings of care, purity, and responsibility. For instance, the Ganga's restoration, as I explore in my research, is entangled with ideas of spiritual purification, urban renewal, public hygiene, and moral improvement. 


As a lifeline for 10% of the world’s population, the Ganga holds outsized importance in achieving global water security. The region grapples with the pressures of population and poverty, unregulated resource utilization, and low productivity, making it a global water scarcity hotspot.  Freshwater scarcity looms large even for countries such as the US that are not usually perceived as water stressed. Thus, learning from the Ganga's restoration, both successes and failures, can benefit countries around the world, which are bound to face similar challenges because of the impact of climate change and continued degradation of freshwater supplies. Moreover, by centering justice and equity in my research, I propose alternate ways of envisioning restoration that delineate abundant futures for rivers and all their human and nonhuman dependents.


This research is the foundation of my doctoral dissertation project, which will be completed by 2026. I plan to actively disseminate the findings to both academic and general audiences. This will involve publishing in peer-reviewed journals, presenting at academic conferences, and giving public talks. Ultimately, this project will not only contribute to anthropological knowledge but also inform my future teaching and research, allowing me to further explore the intersections of environment, culture, and society.
